qas.question: What type of accomidations are domesticated turkey normally grown in?

answers.text: Commercial turkeys are usually reared indoors under controlled conditions

qas.question: What type of conditions are used to increase the weight and profitability of commercial turkeys?

answers.text: The lights can be switched on for 24-hrs/day, or a range of step-wise light regimens to encourage the birds to feed often and therefore grow rapidly

qas.question: At what age is the average turkey considered ready for the initial step of the commercial food process?

answers.text: Females achieve slaughter weight at about 15 weeks of age and males at about 19

qas.question: How much more does a average commercial  turkey weigh in comparison to its wild turkey cousins ?

answers.text: Mature commercial birds may be twice as heavy as their wild counterparts

qas.question: What the average for the amount of  turkeys are consumed in the U.S on Thanksgiving Day?

answers.text: 60 million birds in the United States

qas.question: What are domesticated turkeys no longer grown in?

plausible_answers.text: Females achieve slaughter weight at about 15 weeks of age and males at about 19

context: <a0_0>Commercial turkeys are usually reared <b5_0>indoors under controlled conditions<b5_0/><a0_0/>. These are often large buildings, purpose-built to provide ventilation and low light intensities (this reduces the birds' activity and thereby increases the rate of weight gain). <a1_0><b8_0>The lights can be switched on for 24-hrs/day, or a range of step-wise light regimens to encourage the birds to feed often and therefore grow rapidly<b8_0/><a1_0/>. <a2_0><b6_0>Females achieve slaughter weight at about 15 weeks of age and males at about 19<b6_0/><a2_0/>. <a3_0>Mature commercial birds <b9_0>may be twice as heavy as their wild counterparts<b9_0/><a3_0/>. Many different breeds have been developed, but the majority of commercial birds are white, as this improves the appearance of the dressed carcass, the pin feathers being less visible. Turkeys were at one time mainly consumed on special occasions such as Christmas (10 million birds in the United Kingdom) or Thanksgiving (<a4_0><b7_0>60 million birds<b7_0/> in the United States<a4_0/>). However, they are increasingly becoming part of the everyday diet in many parts of the world.
